Find the number of solutions to the equation
\[\frac{1}{(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)} + \frac{3x^2 - 18x - 22}{(x^2 - 1)(x - 7)} + \frac{3}{x - 2} = \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)}.\]
inference:
First, we factor the denominators to get
\[\frac{1}{(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)} + \frac{3x^2 - 18x - 22}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} + \frac{3}{x - 2} = \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)}.\]Multiplying both sides by $(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)(x - 2)$ gives
\[(x - 2) + (3x^2 - 18x - 22)(x - 2) + 3(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x) = 3(7 - x)(1 + x).\]Expanding, we get
\[x - 2 + 3x^3 - 24x^2 - 14x + 44 + 21x - 3x^3 + 3x = 21 - 3x^2.\]This simplifies to $21x^2 - 20x - 9 = 0.$  By the quadratic formula,
\[x = \frac{20 \pm \sqrt{20^2 + 4 \cdot 21 \cdot 9}}{2 \cdot 21} = \frac{20 \pm \sqrt{1084}}{42} = \frac{10 \pm \sqrt{271}}{21}.\]Both of these solutions are valid, so there are $\boxed{2}$ solutions.

We can move the $\frac{3}{x - 2}$ to the right-hand side.  We can also combine the first two fractions, to get
\begin{align*}
\frac{3x^2 - 18x - 21}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} &= \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} - \frac{3}{x - 2} \\
&= \frac{3 - 3(x - 1)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{6 - 3x}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{3(2 - x)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= -\frac{3}{x - 1}.
\end{align*}Note that $3x^2 - 18x - 21$ factors as $3(x + 1)(x - 7),$ so
\[\frac{3(x + 1)(x - 7)}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This simplifies to
\[\frac{3}{x - 1} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This can never occur, so the number of solutions is $\boxed{0}.$
